game
Class HostPlayer


java.lang.Object

  game.Player

      game.HostPlayer


 class HostPlayer
extends Player

A kind of Player that gets its commands from a remote program, and runs as a host of that remote program. This player does no more than transpond messages between this program and a remote program - a link between two programs, nothing more.

Handling remote communication

Since this player stands in for another computer, and acts as the host of the transaction, this player needs to set up the connection.
Mailbox objects are used to store the messages being sent between computers.
SimpleObjectRegistry objects are used to communicate the remove invocation pointers between the host and the client.

Upon instantiation of this object, two new mailboxes are created - "in" and "out" - which is where the messages will be read from and deposited. The "in" box represents the messages deposited by the client (thus the same as the client's "out" box) while the "out" box is where we deposit messages for the client (thus the same as the client's "in" box). These two objects are both added to a SimpleObjectRegistry, associated with the id given as argument to the constructor. The ClientPlayer uses this id (and the hostname) to find remote pointers to these mailboxes.

The nextCommand() and sendCommand(String msg) simply deposits the appropriate messages into the appropriate boxes. Since the MailBox automatically "freezes" the current thread when it tries to access this mailbox and nothing is deposited there, we do not need to worry about the case where the other program hasn't sent anything, except for a time-out if the other program disappears magically.

Error Handling

If anything goes wrong with the connection itself, we throw the necessary exceptions - IOExceptions as a general rule or their subclass RemoteException if something goes wrong with the connection.

Constant Field Values
Constructor Detail

HostPlayer


HostPlayer(java.lang.String id)

     throws java.io.IOException
A Host for a game named ID on this machine. If there is an error establishing contact, throws an IOException.
This constructor creates and instantiates two actual Mailbox objects, and creates the SimpleObjectRegistry with which these mailboxes will be available to a remote client.

Parameters:
id - the id against which the mailboxes will be stored in the SimpleObjectRegistry.
Throws:
java.io.IOException - if a connection could not be established to the host.
Method Detail

automatedPlayer


Player automatedPlayer()
Description copied from class: Player
Returns an automated version of myself.

Specified by:
automatedPlayer in class Player

close


void close()
Execute any clean-up actions needed to close communications. Closes both the mailboxes. Since it is quite possible for one or both of them to have been closed by the remote program already, we surround this in catch statements and ignore errors.

Overrides:
close in class Player

closeRepository


void closeRepository()
This method closes the registry so that no other client can find this session once a client has connected. Intended to be called when the first command is recieved from a client.

error


void error(java.lang.String msg)
The error handler to let this player know when an error occurred. We need not do anything with this message, seeing that the actual display of errors are left to the different programs' "terminal" players, so we do not need to tell the other person an error occurred. (The remote messaging protocol also does not support this.

Specified by:
error in class Player

flush


void flush(long millis)
Flushes the mailbox. Wait for all queued messages to be received, or MILLIS milliseconds, whichever comes first. During this wait, the Mailbox acts as if full from the point of view of all threads attempting to deposit.

Overrides:
flush in class Player

manualPlayer


Player manualPlayer()
This should not be called, since there is no "manual mode" for Player #2.

Specified by:
manualPlayer in class Player

nextCommand


java.lang.String nextCommand()

                       throws java.io.IOException
Reads the "in" mailbox for the command deposited there by the remote machine. Timeouts after 10 seconds.
The actual recieving is all handled by the remote pointers, we simply call "in.recieve()" with a given timeout value.

Specified by:
nextCommand in class Player
Throws:
java.io.IOException - We throw an IOException with the appropriate message on a timeout or communication issue.

sendCommand


void sendCommand(java.lang.String msg)

           throws java.io.IOException
Deposits the given message in the "out" box.
The actual sending is handled by the remote pointers, we simply call out.deposit with the given message (and of course catch any errors).

Specified by:
sendCommand in class Player
Parameters:
msg - The command the other player just entered.
Throws:
java.io.IOException - if anything in the communcation cycle goes wrong, accompanied with the appropriate message in the error.
